so-called ",["$","em",null,{"children":"destructive"}]," measurements, where the output of the measurement is a classical measurement outcome alone — with no specification of the post-measurement quantum state of whatever system was measured.\nIntuitively speaking, we can imagine that such a measurement destroys the quantum system itself, or that the system is immediately discarded once the measurement is made.\nLater in the lesson we'll broaden our view and consider ",["$","em",null,{"children":"non-destructive"}]," measurements, where there's both a classical measurement outcome and a information, insofar as we can identify probabilistic states with diagonal density matrices.\nSo, in operational terms, we can think about measurements as being channels whose inputs are matrices describing states of whatever system is being measured and whose outputs are ",["$","em",null,{"children":"diagonal"}]," density matrices describing the resulting distribution of measurement outcomes."],"className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":"We'll see shortly that any channel having this property can always be written in a simple, canonical form that ties directly to the description of measurements as collections of positive semidefinite matrices.\nConversely, given an arbitrary measurement as a collection of matrices, there's always a valid channel having the diagonal output property that describes the given measurement as suggested in the previous paragraph.\nPutting these observations together, we find that the two descriptions of general measurements are equivalent.","className":"group paragraph-el text-text-primary mx-0"}],"\n",["$","p",null,{"children":"Before proceeding further, let's be more precise about that are collectively in a quantum state, and a general measurement is performed on one of the systems.\nThis results in one of the measurement outcomes, selected at random according to probabilities
